name: 5-bromoindole
Reason: 5-bromoindole has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The indole ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-system, estimated at around +20 °C. The bromine atom introduces a significant dipole moment, which can increase the melting point due to hydrogen bonding and rigidity, estimated at around +10 °C. The methyl group can also contribute to the melting point due to its effect on the crystal lattice, estimated at around +5 °C.
